displayed_text: Patient: …my feet the most yeah… Doctor: Are tingling? Patient: Yeah, yeah I’ve been getting and it shrinks and so I’m saying wow. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: What the hell man. I don’t like that feeling. I don’t like… Doctor: No. Patient: It paralyzes or something. I don’t like that feeling. Doctor: Yeah. No, I don’t want to wait until you get paralyzed either. Patient: It would be in my arms. Doctor: Right. Patient: It would be in my arms and my feet, my toes. Doctor: Yeah, because, but we don’t want to wait until you know it totally messes up with your… Doctor: …walking and stuff.

Patient: I can tell him thanks for buying her a new car. Doctor: He didn’t buy it. Healthcare Professional: She probably bought it (chuckles) Patient: Oh it’s you – it’s your it’s everybodies - it’s both your monies; it’s not just - Doctor: No, no, he is just, yeah. No, but he’s really trying to drive it as much as he can right now. Healthcare Professional: Yours? Doctor: The problem, well the worst thing is my son sent a picture to all of his friends and you know my sister; he sent it to his cousin, my sister’s kids and so they told my sister and I hadn’t had a chance to tell her that I bought this car. And she’s like, “Are you out of your mind? You bought N____ a Mercedes?” (Chuckles) Healthcare Professional: Oh they thought it was N___’s car. Doctor: He sort of - sent the text out as if it was his car with a picture of my car. HCP OH! Family Member: His car. Oh my! Doctor: But now he doesn’t have any car because he’s in college. He doesn’t have - HCP Oh okay! Family Member: The Mercedes Patient: He’s lucky he’s having college paid for.

Patient: I ain’t got no problem with flying. Doctor: No. Go do it. Patient: I want that jet. Doctor: I know. Go get it. Patient: I want that jet. I get the jet I’m good. Doctor: You’ll have a great time. Patient: Yeah. I’m gonna have a great time on my bike. Doctor: Okay. Just be careful. People worry. That’s all. Patient: I know, I know. I know how to you know make her shut it down. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Call me if you run into trouble. If there’s issues with your insurance we will let you know. Patient: Well doc we ain’t claiming that. Remember you said that last time and we made it.

Patient: So I all need to do now is go back to the lab and do… Doctor: No, no you’re probably gonna stay here and S__ will take you over because those are special tubes that she has to send out and all that. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: And would it be possible for me to have copies of that stuff? Doctor: Yeah I thought you might I know you usually want some. This is the bone scan. Patient: And my PSA wasn’t on the sheet. Do you guys have a number on that? Doctor: It’s not back. Did you do it yesterday? No today. Patient: We did labs today. Doctor: Oh, okay. No it’s not back yet then. I’ll take a look and let you know but Patient: Okay. Doctor: If it’s back. Family Member: Next Friday we’ll be back to plan out the next step and…

Family Member: -so he would continue to take the Xtandi along with the chemo? Doctor: No, we would stop it. Family Member: Okay, then I was gonna say I kind of misinterpreted that. Doctor: Yeah, we just stop the Xtandi. Patient: Continue it until I start the trial? Doctor: Nope, you just stop it. It's not doing its thing. If you want to do the trial, or if you're okay with chemo as the next step. But either way Xtandi’s not doing it. So we need to bail out of that. It's just giving you side effects with no gain. Family Member: So how soon would you try to start the new treatment Doctor: I think there's like a good at least two to three week washout you know we got to let that one get out of your system. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: -and then start the new thing. Family Member: Oh I didn’t realize that. Doctor: Otherwise you can get drug interaction- Family Member: Okay.

Patient: Yes, I have the time. Yeah. Doctor: Time is one thing, but again you know what the cancer is going to do is the other. Patient: Side effects and all that, yeah, I don’t know what, yeah. Doctor: So those would be potentially three options. If we’re going to go chemotherapy, whether we add in the Vitamin C or not; you get the infusion, you don’t know whether it’s the real thing or Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you get the real chemo. The other one is the immune therapy which my reservation at this point is the gasping thing. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So as you follow up with the lung doctors and then Dr. G__ and I just need to know who’s going to order the scans to say the Enzalutamide is not working anymore. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And we would keep you on it if we’re going to do the immuno-therapy study. We would stop it if we were going to go to chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, and then the first-in-human study—I don’t know whether we have slots right now.

Patient: Yeah. I was thinking to go down Y___. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. You can go there, definitely. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Or, you know, at SM___’s, there is a neurosurgeon who’s very good. Family Member: Now, does he ever see, does he have-? Patient: SM___’s, where? Doctor: Here, L___, so, like a few miles from here. Patient: Oh, L___, oh. Could you get me the, his card, or something? Doctor: I’ll give you his phone number, yeah. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. He’s specifically a spine surgeon. I’ve known him for many years. Patient: Oh, I see. Okay. Family Member: Oh. That makes sense.

Healthcare Professional: Yeah, she doesn’t start I.V.’s. They have to have the I.V. tech start them. Doctor: for chemo. HCP Okay, I’m going to take these to K____. Patient: Uh you know if you’re uh if you’re driving around in a Mercedes, the least you could do is order a nice pen. (conversation in background) Doctor: Oh my turnover of pens is crazy. I never have fancy pens because I lose them. Patient: Your husband has a bunch of ‘em. They have their nice pens. Doctor: Oh my gosh; I didn’t know that. Family Member: He said he hides them. Doctor: I guess I don’t even. I didn’t even know that. Patient: Oh yeah, because I took one when I was down there and the guy (she gets after me for swiping people’s pens) Doctor: So mine are, you’re allowed to swipe. (Laughs) Patient: Yeah, you can throw these away. (chuckles) Doctor: Well I use them so much; I mean I run out of ink and then I need to be able to toss and then move on to the next one.

Patient: So we get the shot right here? Doctor: Yeah. Yes. So how do you like the new trailer? Slowly, then the scans, everything is going to move here. Patient: Really? Doctor: Two years. Patient: Two years? Yeah. Family Member: Are they building a bigger building? Doctor: They are. Okay. That’s fine. Going to expand quite a bit. We were kind of bursting at the seams there so they needed to do it, but it’s going to be on a much bigger scale. Patient: I like coming here better. Doctor: Yes. Definitely. I mean it’s much more in and out, it’s a smaller place, and there are- Patient: It’s hectic down there. Doctor: Yes. Yes. Patient: Tell you? (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah. It is a much bigger place. But it needs to be with the hospital and everything.

Patient: And she started taking this fluorescence. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Are you familiar with that? Doctor: Uh-uh. What does that do? Family Member: Purifies the toxins inside your body. Patient: Detoxes, detoxification. Doctor: Okay. Alright. Family Member: Is that good for him to be taking? Doctor: Yeah. No. You’re on a medicine that interacts with everything known to mankind. XTANDI is, remember we talked about how it’s processed through the liver? So it’d be good if you don’t add on extra stuff that will tax your liver that would make the XTANDI either work less or more. More is not necessarily better, and it might make you have more side effects. Family Member: Have you heard of fluorescence? Doctor: Never heard of it. But in general we try to stay away from too many supplements on drugs like XTANDI because it is a known interactor Family Member: Oh. Oh. It’s not a drug. It’s like a homeopathic. Doctor: of many existing drugs. You have to be careful. Right. But all of those are drugs. They really are.

Patient: Okay as far as working what do you mean by that? I mean is it something… Doctor: Working against – shrinking the cancer and helping – working against the… Family Member: Targeting drugs and genes (doc and fam talking at the same time.) Doctor: Targeting exactly the cancer that you have. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now there is another option, I know you’re completely reluctant to go on chemotherapy. You know there is obviously that would be the standard treatment that you know we would – if we advise that and if you decide you want that you could easily get it in lots and closer to home. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: But there is a newer hormonal therapy that also we can consider for you. Now that is sort of an earlier phase trial, so it’s a phase one trial. Okay. But the advantage is that we’ve already been through a number of the dosing levels. So typically a phase one trial is where you’re getting something very new that’s worked amazingly well in the lab that now you’re testing in people. So the first few dose levels really are trying to see what kind of side effects and what dose level really has… Patient: Sure. Doctor: But you’ll have some long days and things like that, you would have the hotel and mileage covered you know same as this study for that matter. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. (clears throat) Doctor: So those things would be covered, but it is a matter of whether you’re willing to come back and forth.

Patient: Thank you, Yeah thank you. Doctor: So it’s finally actually going in the right direction. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But you will need to continue on the prednisone also which I forgot to ask you are you still on that? Patient: I’m still taking it yeah. Doctor: Perfect so you know the job isn’t done, but once we get more chemo on board you should feel better. But also just pain medicine wise, so what are you taking? Anything right now? Family Member: He’s vaping. Doctor: Okay that’s probably not going to do anything. Right? Patient: Um it gave me a little bit and maybe it’s just a mental thing. Doctor: Mm hmm. Patient: Give a little bit of comfort. Doctor: Um hum. Well and you could do that, but I think there are other true medicines that you could try to kind of knock down the pain.

Patient: because that’s another problem I’m having to get my doctor to maybe get that taken, Doctor: Yeah. Patient: but it don’t hurt walking Doctor: No. Patient: or doing anything so. Doctor: Yeah, so you’ve seen a surgeon specifically for the hernia? Patient: No, I’ve just seen my regular doctor. Family Member: He just told me. He was hiding it from me. Doctor: Ah. Well, you know, getting that sort of worked out because we could always do that in the between. Just because this is a six month go Patient: Right. Okay. Okay. Doctor: we can always pause because hernia surgery is outpatient nowadays too so you just need healing time. Patient: Right.

Family Member: Because kidneys wouldn’t do that. It wouldn’t push back and forth like that. Doctor: No and if it’s the lymph nodes that are pushing, there may be a little bit of pain from that. Family Member: From one side to the other but.. Doctor: Yeah. But it’s still, it doesn’t sound cancer related. It almost sounds muscle or… Family Member: I think his back’s out of whack. Doctor: Or back. Family Member: He does see a chiropractor. Doctor: Okay. Patient: On occasion I do. Plus I started swinging golf clubs again and mowed the lawn. Family Member: That explains it. Patient: So I got stuff going on here. Doctor: After next week it’s gonna be much more in pain then if you’re gonna make him work hard. (Laughs)

Patient: Ow! Doctor: That’s the same (speaking softly) Patient: No. Patient: Awww. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Okay so and you had quite a bit of this current chemotherapy that you’ve been on. Okay so we’ve given you about twelve cycles, but the good thing is it has worked and has kept the cancer in check all this time. The other good thing is that I didn’t see any other new areas. So the lung, liver, none of those were involved. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So what I’m going to suggest is that we change to a different kind of chemotherapy. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because the advantage is that you know this mass that is resistant to the current chemotherapy will hopefully… Patient: Do you think that, you think that… Doctor: Respond. Patient: Okay. Nah you can keep Dr. V____.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White
